definitions.definition: To go in the reverse direction .
examples: The train backed into the station.
I back you all the way.
Which horse are you backing in this race?

definitions.definition: To change direction contrary to the normal pattern ; that is, to shift anticlockwise in the northern hemisphere, or clockwise in the southern hemisphere.
To brace the yards so that the wind presses on the front of the sail, to slow the ship .
To lay out a second, smaller anchor to provide additional holding power.
To stand still behind another dog which has pointed.

examples: The mugger backed her into a corner and demanded her wallet.

definitions.definition: To get upon the back of; to mount .
To place or seat upon the back.
To make a back for; to furnish with a back.
To adjoin behind; to be at the back of.
To write upon the back of, possibly as an endorsement .
examples: to back a letter;  to back a note or legal document

definitions.definition: To sign or endorse (a warrant, issued in another county, to apprehend an offender).
labels: of a justice of the peace
definitions.label_groups: law , of a justice of the peace

definitions.definition: To draw from behind the back (a knife etc.) ( as also back out ) .
To carry an infant on one’s back.

main_definition: ( intransitive ) To go in the reverse direction .
secondary_definitions: ( nautical , of the wind ) To change direction contrary to the normal pattern ; that is, to shift anticlockwise in the northern hemisphere, or clockwise in the southern hemisphere.
( nautical , of a square sail ) To brace the yards so that the wind presses on the front of the sail, to slow the ship .
( nautical , of an anchor ) To lay out a second, smaller anchor to provide additional holding power.
( UK , of a hunting dog ) To stand still behind another dog which has pointed.
( transitive ) To push or force backwards.
( transitive , obsolete ) To get upon the back of; to mount .
( transitive , obsolete ) To place or seat upon the back.
To make a back for; to furnish with a back.
To adjoin behind; to be at the back of.
To write upon the back of, possibly as an endorsement .
( law , of a justice of the peace ) To sign or endorse (a warrant, issued in another county, to apprehend an offender).
( MLE , transitive ) To draw from behind the back (a knife etc.) ( as also back out ) .
( Nigeria , transitive ) To carry an infant on one’s back.
